author: bridge-bot
content: <CarlBeek> yup, fully expect it to be IPFS-able. the caveat being, weâ€™ll probably be rolling several ux updates over time so thereâ€™ll be a few versions/hashes

author: bridge-bot
content:
<kevaundray> > <kevaundray>  Thatâ€™s a good question.

The sequencer is not  forced to include your contribution.

There are a few places where they can be malicious and not include it:

- your contribution is valid and for some malicious reason they says itâ€™s invalid.

Here you can try to use tor and an Ethereum address, in the case that the sequencer was unfairly targeting you by demographic or by GitHub username.

- your contribution is valid, the sequencer says itâ€™s valid, but then does not include it.

As a part of the protocol the sequencer gives you a signed receipt for your contribution, so if they do not include it, then you can brandish the receipt as proof. The consequence of this is left to social consensus. Here itâ€™s more of a case by case basis and weâ€™d need to figure out why it was not included.

The first scenario seems kind of dire, but if the sequencer is indiscriminately rejecting contributions, then most likely there is something wrong with the implementation itself (re @kzg_ceremony_bot: <Trent Van Epps> https://twitter.com/bbuddha_xyz/status/1573877277213229058?s=21)

author: bridge-bot
content: <kevaundray> The backstop is that the sequencers are only ran by reputable entities (though this does not exclude them being hacked)
